section-block.rac_essential-question: How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and Illustrated by Janan Cain
section-block.rac_book_summary: Feelings are a normal part of life. We all have them. This book shows children expressing a range of diverse emotions. Colorful illustrations and rhyming text make it a fun way to learn about feelings.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about feelings. Ask them how many different feelings they can name. Ask them which of those are they feeling right now?
Invite children to create a series of movements based on different feelings. For example, we might shake when we’re scared and frown when we’re angry.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Way I Feel, written and illustrated by Janan Cain.
Scout loves to read informational texts. In this book, he will learn about all of his different feelings.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we finish the book. Ready?
What different feelings can people have?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The boy in the story says he is shaking. Why do you think he is shaking?
The girl feels disappointed that her friend can’t come over to play with her. What’s an example of a time you felt disappointed?
Sometimes we get sad and we don’t want to do anything. What clues tell us that the boy is sad? (MB)
What does the boy do to show that he is angry? What do you do when you are angry? (MB)
The boy says he feels blue. Why might the boy feel blue? (MB)
We learned about many different feelings today. Make a face that shows the feeling you liked most.
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What different feelings can people have?
section.rac_body-text: Now, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: People can feel happy or sad.
People can feel thankful or frustrated.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about feelings you’ve had as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is being sad a feeling that people can have?
Being sad is a f______ (feeling) that people can have.
Being sad is a feeling that people can have.
What feelings do you have when you visit a new place?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: It’s easy to monitor the physical development of children at this age, as we see them getting taller, bigger, and stronger before our eyes. It takes more work to assess their social-emotional development, but it’s important to do so. Take special note of children’s understanding of feelings, both in themselves and in others.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Identify the Feelings of Others
section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss with children how important it is to try to understand the feelings that other people have and their own feelings. Ask what do they do to help when a friend or family member is feeling sad? Angry? Disappointed? Ask if they also feel that way sometimes? Discuss why it is good to learn how to recognize different feelings.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book The Way I Feel, written and illustrated by Janan Cain, to look at how the people in the story express their emotions.
Clifford has lots of different feelings and so do his friends. Right now he feels happy because he loves reading stories that are about feelings.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book and talk about how we can identify the feelings of the different people in the story. (MB)
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The boy says that sometimes when he feels sad, he doesn’t know why he feels that way. Do you ever feel sad without knowing why? What do you do? (MB)
How can you tell that the girl in the picture is feeling shy? Do you ever feel shy when you meet new people? (MB)
What are some clues that tell you that someone is excited? Have you ever felt really excited? When? (MB)
The girl shouts, “‘I did it! I did it!’ I shout to the crowd.” She shouts because she feels proud. Why does she feel proud? What is the girl doing to show that she is proud? (MB)
The children on the pages are showing different feelings. What feelings can you see? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to play “What’s My Feeling?” Have them work in small groups and tell each person in the group to show a feeling without using any words. The other people in the group have to say what feeling the child is showing. If they can’t think of any more feelings to portray, remind them of the ones discussed in The Way I Feel. Then try the same activity with children using only words to show the feeling without body movements.
Ask the children which of these they found to be easier: identifying feelings by seeing how people move their bodies or by hearing what they say about their feelings.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about identifying feelings in themselves and in others.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Learning to identify all feelings in a positive way helps children to nurture the skills they need to become healthy and well-adjusted children and adults. Learning to identify the feelings of others not only gives children a better understanding of their own emotions, it helps them to develop empathy and build stronger friendships (kidshelpline.com.au/understanding feelings).

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to use what they already know to understand the book.
Make different facial expressions for different emotions, and have children guess how you are feeling. Ask, “Who knows how I feel?” Then, “How do you know?”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to revisit The Way I Feel, written and illustrated by Janan Cain.
Scout loves The Way I Feel because he wants to learn how to identify the feelings that his friends have.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we finish the book. Ready?
What makes you feel happy or proud?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language usage.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What a funny drawing! What makes the girl feel silly? (MB)
Look at the girl on the swing. She looks so happy! What makes you feel happy?
The boy says, “I shout with a mighty roar.” Do you think the boy is being quiet or is he being loud? Why?
How can you tell that the girl is feeling thankful? (MB)
The girl suddenly feels shy when she meets someone new. When was a time that you felt shy?
The girl feels proud because she got dressed all by herself. What makes you feel proud?
Did you use what you already know about feelings as we read the story today? Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question: What makes you feel happy or proud?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share their thinking.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I feel happy when I play with my friends.
I feel proud when I learn a new word.
I feel happy when my teacher reads my favorite book.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about feelings, inviting children to share how they show different emotions.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do you feel happy or surprised when you play with your friends?
I feel h______ (happy) when I play with my friends.
I feel happy when I play with my friends.
What can you do to show that you are happy?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: While multilingual learners may be struggling with English, the emotions human beings feel are universal. Examining them together can create entry points into topics that would otherwise be too difficult. At the same time, it’s important to be sensitive to cultural differences and emotional cues that may vary among different groups.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion about everything they have learned about feelings this week. Talk about how this knowledge might help them in the future.
Play “Simon Says” with children using phrases such as “Simon says look happy” or “Simon says look angry.” Remind children to respond only when you say “Simon Says.”
Introduce two new words that we’ll use today.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a poster called If You’re Happy and You Know It. It’s all about feelings.
Scout loves to look at posters. He thinks this poster tells us a lot of good information about feelings!
The Way I Feel and If You’re Happy and You Know It are about the different feelings that people have. Let’s see if we can find connections between the two.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show The Way I Feel book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
How do we talk about and manage our feelings?

section.rac_body-text: Read the Big Chart aloud, and then use the following prompts to discuss the poster.
Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can come point to the child who is scared? Is that how you look when you’re scared? (MB)
Who can point to the child who is acting silly? What are some ways that you like to act silly? (MB)
Why do you think this boy might be surprised? How do you look when you’re surprised? (MB)
Who can come point to the girl who is feeling loved? What shape is she making with her hands? Why do you think she’s making that shape? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: After children sing the words to “If You’re Happy and You Know It” on the back of the poster, challenge them to come up with other verses to the song that talk about feelings not mentioned on the poster. They can use the book The Way I Feel as inspiration. For example, “If you’re proud and you know it, shout hooray!”
Provide a writing prompt about feelings, inviting children to share what they learned about their own feelings. Give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: The highest rate of vocabulary development occurs during the preschool years. While feelings have a strong nonverbal component, young children must learn the words to talk about their feelings with competence and compassion.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite each child to choose a feeling to act out. Then have them march around the room in a Feelings Parade to celebrate all of the feelings they read about this week.
Write the letters H, S, L, and A for children. Make the sound of each letter. Ask children to say the letter then say the feeling that starts with that letter. Model this for children.
Introduce two new words that we will use today.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and act out the book The Way I Feel, written and illustrated by Janan Cain.
This informational text uses colorful pictures and interesting text. Scout enjoys looking at the pictures and seeing how the words appear in different ways.
This week we read about the different feelings we can all have. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
How can you feel better when you are sad?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: It looks like the girl threw some dishes on the floor because she was disappointed. Do you think that was a good idea? Show me a thumbs up or a thumbs down.
The boy in the tree feels sad. What could he do to feel better? (MB)
The girl feels frustrated because she is having a hard time tying her shoes. Can you think of a time when you were frustrated? What did you do?
The boy can’t play outside because it is raining. What fun things could he do inside so that he does not feel bored? (MB)
The girl says she is jealous when she has to share. What would you say to her to make her feel better?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How can you feel better when you are sad?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: When I feel sad, I can talk to a friend or family member.
When I feel sad, I can take a deep breath.
When I feel sad, I can play with my friends.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about their feelings and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: When you are sad, do you shake or do you take a deep breath?
When I am sad, I take a deep br________ (breath).
When I am sad, I take a deep breath.
What do you do when you feel angry?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Just as physical exercise and nutrition are important parts of a healthy lifestyle for young children, so is learning how to access, understand, and self-regulate their feelings. Developing a healthy relationship with their feelings will serve them for many years to come.
